International Downloads">{{cite web | title = Sunbird - International Downloads | publisher = mozilla.org | url = http://www.mozilla.org/projects/calendar/sunbird/l10n_download.html | accessdate = 2007-06-12 }}</ref> EULA in English only<ref name=mozeula>{{cite web | url = http://www.mozilla.org/legal/eula | title = Mozilla Sunbird [[Software license agreement|End-User Software Licensing Agreement]] | accessdate = 2007-06-12 | publisher = mozilla.org}}</ref> | genre = [[Personal information manager]] | license = [[Mozilla Public License|MPL]], MPL/[[GNU General Public License|GPL]]/[[LGPL]] tri-license | website = [http://www.mozilla.org/projects/calendar/sunbird/ Project Homepage] }} '''Mozilla Sunbird''' is a [[free and open source software|free and open source]], [[cross-platform]] [[calendaring software|calendar application]] that was developed by the [[Mozilla Foundation]], [[Sun Microsystems]] and many volunteers.<ref name="volunteerlist">[http://www.mozilla.org/credits/ Mozilla contributors list], ''Mozilla.org''</ref> Mozilla Sunbird was described as "... a cross platform standalone calendar application based on Mozilla's [[XUL]] user interface language."<ref name="mainsunbirdpage">[http://www.mozilla.org/projects/calendar/sunbird/index.html The Sunbird Project - Standalone Calendar] - Main project page describing the project.</ref> Announced in July 2003,<ref name="sunbirdAnnounced">[http://www.mozillazine.org/talkback.html?article=3432 Mozilla Sunbird Standalone Calendar Project Launches - MozillaZine Talkback] - MozillaZine article announcing the Sunbird Project</ref> Sunbird is a standalone version of the [[Mozilla Calendar Project]].
It was developed as a standalone version of the [[Lightning (software)|Lightning]] calendar and scheduling extension for [[Mozilla Thunderbird]]. Development of Sunbird was ended with release 1.0 beta 1 to focus on development of [[Lightning (software)|Mozilla Lightning]].<ref>[http://www.mozilla.org/projects/calendar/releases/sunbird1.0b1.html Sunbird 1.0 beta1 Release Notes]: "This is the last public Sunbird release by the Calendar Project." . Retrieved 2010-04-01.</ref><ref>[http://weblogs.mozillazine.org/calendar/2009/02/calendar_project_at_a_critical.html Calendar Project at a critical juncture], Calendar Weblog. Retrieved 2010-04-01.</ref>
==Sun contributions== Sun Microsystems contributed significantly to the Lightning extension project to provide users with an alternative free and open source choice to [[Microsoft Office]] by combining [[OpenOffice.org]] and Thunderbird/Lightning.<ref>{{cite web|last=Paquet |first=Simon |url=http://weblogs.mozillazine.org/calendar/2006/10/sun_microsystems_announces_int.html |title=Calendar Weblog |publisher=Weblogs.mozillazine.org |date=2006-10-05 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref> Sun's key focus areas in addition to general bug fixing were calendar views, team/collaboration features and support for the [[Sun Java Calendar Server|Sun Java System Calendar Server]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.openoffice.org/editorial/mozilla_lightning_and_OOo.html |title=Interview On Mozilla Lighting and |publisher=Openoffice.org |date= |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref> Since both projects share the same code base, any contribution to one of them is a direct contribution to the other.
==Trademark issues and Iceowl== {{Main|Mozilla Corporation software rebranded by the Debian project}} Although released under a [[Mozilla Public License|MPL]], MPL/[[GNU General Public License|GPL]]/[[LGPL]] tri-license, Mozilla Sunbird suffers from trademark restrictions that prevent the distribution of modified versions with the Mozilla branding.
As a result the [[Debian]] project created [[Iceowl]], a virtually identical version sans the branding restrictions.
